Two days earlier, he removed a hangnail, prompting redness that has worsened significantly despite soaking his finger in warm water and applying an over-the-counter topical antibiotic. He says that he has not been biting or sucking on his fingers.
He is afebrile. The lateral nail fold of the affected finger exhibits significant edema with surrounding erythema extending to the distal interphalangeal joint (figure).
What is the optimal management approach for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Incision and drainage plus oral cephalexin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

When the infection does not respond to incision and drainage, or when there are indications of more extensive involvement of the hand or cellulitis (as in this case), oral antibiotic therapy is often added. The use of an oral antibiotic such as cephalexin alone would be insufficient.

B) CORRECT:

Acute paronychia is typically caused by acute penetrating trauma, such as nail biting, aggressive manicuring, or hangnail removal. Warm compresses or soaks along with topical antibacterial agents, such as mupirocin, may be sufficient for mild cases of paronychia. If an abscess has formed, as in this case, surgical incision and drainage is the definitive treatment. When the infection does not respond to incision and drainage, or when there are indications of more extensive involvement of the hand or cellulitis (as in this case), oral antibiotic therapy is often added.

Staphylococcus aureus and streptococci are the most common organisms that cause paronychia when other risk factors (finger sucking, nail biting, comorbidities) are not present. In patients who bite or suck on their fingers, mouth flora (such as Eikenella corrodens, Hemophilus influenza, and oral anaerobic bacteria) may also be involved, and treatment with a broad-spectrum antibiotic, such as amoxicillin-clavulanate, may be necessary. If antibiotic therapy is given, coverage for methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) with a drug such as trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole should be considered in areas where MRSA is common or in patients with risk factors for resistant infection.

Key learning point: The optimal way to manage acute paronychia with abscess of the finger and surrounding cellulitis is incision and drainage plus oral antibiotics.

C) INCORRECT:

Antifungal therapy, such as oral fluconazole, is not indicated for acute paronychia.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical glucocorticoids, such as hydrocortisone, are not routinely indicated for the treatment of acute paronychia.

E) INCORRECT:

Warm compresses or soaks along with topical antibacterial agents, such as mupirocin, may be sufficient for mild cases of paronychia. If an abscess has formed, as in this case, the use of a topical antibiotic and warm compresses alone would be insufficient.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a purpuric rash. He recently completed induction chemotherapy with daunorubicin plus cytarabine for acute myelogenous leukemia.
Upon evaluation, he is arousable and states that he feels extremely tired. His temperature is 40.1°C, his heart rate is 110 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 85/40 mm Hg. A purpuric plaque with ulceration is present on his thigh (figure).
Laboratory testing reveals an absolute neutrophil count of 245 per mm3 (reference range, 1900–7600).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sweet syndrome is associated with acute myelogenous leukemia and certain medications, such as colony-stimulating factors. It usually manifests as edematous, red, or violaceous plaques and nodules. Although both pyoderma gangrenosum and Sweet syndrome can manifest with ulcerated violaceous plaques, neither condition is likely to cause the hypotension seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Pyoderma gangrenosum and Sweet syndrome are neutrophilic dermatoses characterized by sterile infiltration of neutrophils into the dermis. Pyoderma gangrenosum manifests as an ulcer with a rolled purple border and may exhibit pathergy, but it is not commonly associated with neutropenic sepsis.

C) INCORRECT:

Leukemia cutis is characterized by violaceous to purpuric papules, plaques, and nodules on the skin and oral mucosa. These lesions rarely ulcerate and become necrotic. Leukemia cutis can occur at any time during the course of leukemia but would be uncommon shortly after induction chemotherapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Calciphylaxis manifests as purpuric patches with firm, indurated surrounding plaques, usually in areas of increased adipose tissue. It is most often associated with end-stage kidney disease.

E) CORRECT:

Ecthyma gangrenosum is a skin infection often caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacteremia. Other gram-negative rods, fungal species, and Staphylococcus aureus are less commonly involved but have also been reported. Patients with ecthyma gangrenosum present with a purpuric patch, most often on the buttocks and thighs, with overlying necrosis and eventual eschar formation. Early detection and prompt initiation of therapy against P. aeruginosa is imperative.

Key learning point: In a neutropenic patient who presents with sepsis and necrotic purpuric plaques on the thighs and/or buttocks, an important infection to consider is ecthyma gangrenosum (Pseudomonas aeruginosa septicemia).

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman with no significant medical history reports a 4-day history of swelling and pain in her right inguinal area. She appreciated increased swelling and tenderness a few days after noticing an ingrown hair in the area. She has no history of skin infections.
She has a temperature of 38.2°C and appears well. Along her right inguinal crease is a 7-cm x 5-cm area of induration with central fluctuance. The area is tender to palpation, especially toward the central portion. There is no erythema, streaking, or crepitus. The rest of her examination is unrevealing.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate to manage this patient’s skin lesion?

choices.text: Perform incision and drainage, followed by treatment with intravenous cefazolin for 10 days
Refer the patient for hospitalization and intravenous linezolid
Perform incision and drainage, and prescribe oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Indications for intravenous antibiotic treatment include high fevers, rapid progression of infection, abscesses overlying joint spaces or the hands or feet, and failure of outpatient therapy with oral antibiotics. This patient does not have signs indicating the need for intravenous antibiotics. Furthermore, cefazolin alone would not be the best choice for an abscess likely due to MRSA, because beta-lactam antibiotics do not cover this organism,

B) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics alone, either oral or intravenous, without incision and drainage, is not sufficient for management of an abscess.

C) INCORRECT:

Indications for hospitalization and intravenous antibiotic treatment include high fevers, rapid progression of infection, abscesses overlying joint spaces or the hands or feet, and failure of outpatient therapy with oral antibiotics. This patient does not have signs indicating the need for intravenous antibiotics or hospitalization. Although linezolid covers MRSA, the absence of high fever, exquisite pain, or crepitus indicates that a rapidly progressing infection, such as necrotizing fasciitis, is also unlikely, and there is no indication for linezolid without incision and drainage.

D) INCORRECT:

In the presence of cellulitis, Streptococcus pyogenes could be considered as a potential pathogen, and a beta-lactam antibiotic should be included in the empiric coverage. However, this patient does not have signs of cellulitis, and cephalexin alone would not be the best choice for an abscess likely due to MRSA.

E) CORRECT:

Given this patient's clinical signs and symptoms and the moderately large area of induration and fluctuance around the site of a prior skin lesion, the patient likely has an abscess secondary to Staphylococcus aureus. The absence of erythema suggests that an overlying cellulitis is unlikely, and the absence of high fever, exquisite pain, or crepitus indicates that a rapidly progressing infection, such as necrotizing fasciitis, is also unlikely.

Definitive treatment for a large abscess, as in this case, consists of incision and drainage plus an antibiotic, such as trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) or doxycycline, that cover community-acquired methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). A recent study demonstrated that providing TMP-SMX after incision and drainage of an abscess resulted in higher rates of clinical cure than incision and drainage alone. In another trial, involving abscesses <5 cm in size where the causative organism was MRSA in 67% of cases, the cure rate was similar in groups receiving clindamycin or TMP-SMX after incision and drainage (around 82%), and both groups had higher cure rates than the placebo group (69%).

In the presence of cellulitis, Streptococcus pyogenes could be considered as a potential pathogen, and a beta-lactam antibiotic should be included in the empiric coverage, because TMP-SMX does not cover this organism.

Key learning point: A patient who has symptoms and signs of a moderately large skin abscess without overlying cellulitis but with some systemic inflammatory symptoms should be managed with incision and drainage as well as oral antibiotics.

questions.text:
A healthy 30-year-old man reports bumps on his legs that are occasionally itchy and that come and go but are particularly bothersome in the summer. He has not been in any pools, lakes, or hot tubs recently. He otherwise feels well.
Physical examination reveals 1- to 2-mm papules and pustules centered around hair follicles and scattered on the patient’s thigh (figure). No comedones are visualized, and the patient does not have lesions elsewhere on his body.
Which one of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient’s rash?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous herpes simplex virus infections are characterized by grouped vesicles, papules, or pustules on an erythematous base, often on the lips or buttocks. They do not appear as scattered, follicle-based papules and pustules, as seen in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa can cause folliculitis in patients exposed to contaminated water, such as in pools and hot tubs. Folliculitis caused by Pseudomonas may appear in exposed areas of the legs and may have more peripheral erythema.

C) INCORRECT:

Candida albicans can cause folliculitis in immunocompromised patients, especially when they have candidemia. It can also cause pustular folliculitis in the skin folds of immunocompetent patients. However, it is not the most likely causative agent in this healthy, young patient whose folliculitis occurs exclusively on the legs.

D) INCORRECT:

Cutibacterium acnes, a gram-positive bacterium, is linked to the development of acne. Acne can appear as scattered papules and pustules, similar to folliculitis, but it usually also has concomitant open and closed comedones (blackheads and whiteheads, respectively). This is because unlike folliculitis, acne results from an alteration (with or without inflammation) in the follicular apparatus. Comedones are the uninflamed lesions, whereas papules, pustules, and nodules are the inflamed lesions.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has folliculitis, a condition that can occur when there is inflammation of the superficial hair follicle.

Folliculitis is commonly exacerbated by hot weather, tight-fitting clothing, and shaving. It can be caused by a variety of organisms, but the most common is Staphylococcus aureus. Obtaining a proper history of comorbid conditions, exposures, and medications can be helpful in determining the causative organism.

Mild bacterial folliculitis is treated with topical therapies such as mupirocin cream, clindamycin lotion or solution, and benzoyl peroxide. More extensive folliculitis may require oral antibiotics such as cephalexin or doxycycline. Wound cultures in these cases may be helpful in directing treatment but are not typically necessary.

Key learning point: Staphylococcus aureus is the organism most likely to cause bacterial folliculitis in an otherwise healthy patient without exposure to other relevant organisms.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl with no significant medical history reports a 4-day history of swelling and pain in her right inguinal area. She appreciated increased swelling and tenderness a few days after noticing an ingrown hair in the area. She has no history of skin infections.
She has a temperature of 38.2°C and appears well. Along her right inguinal crease is a 7-cm x 5-cm area of induration with central fluctuance. The area is tender to palpation, especially toward the central portion. There is no erythema, streaking, or crepitus. The rest of her examination is unrevealing.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate to manage this patient’s skin lesion?

choices.text: Perform incision and drainage, and prescribe oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
Perform incision and drainage, followed by treatment with intravenous cefazolin for 10 days
Refer the patient for hospitalization and intravenous linezolid

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Given this patient's clinical signs and symptoms and the moderately large area of induration and fluctuance around the site of a prior skin lesion, the patient likely has an abscess secondary to Staphylococcus aureus. The absence of erythema suggests that an overlying cellulitis is unlikely, and the absence of high fever, exquisite pain, or crepitus indicates that a rapidly progressing infection, such as necrotizing fasciitis, is also unlikely.

Definitive treatment for a large abscess, as in this case, consists of incision and drainage plus an antibiotic, such as trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX), that covers community-acquired methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Alternative antibiotics that cover MRSA include doxycycline and clindamycin. A recent study demonstrated that providing TMP-SMX after incision and drainage of an abscess resulted in higher rates of clinical cure than incision and drainage alone. In another trial, involving abscesses <5 cm in size where the causative organism was MRSA in 67% of cases, the cure rate was similar in groups receiving clindamycin or TMP-SMX after incision and drainage (around 82%), and both groups had higher cure rates than the placebo group (69%).

Antibiotics alone, either oral or intravenous, without incision and drainage, is not sufficient for management of an abscess.

Although TMP-SMX is adequate treatment for an abscess, it would not be sufficient treatment if the patient also had signs and symptoms of cellulitis. In the presence of cellulitis, Streptococcus pyogenes could be considered as a potential pathogen, and a beta-lactam antibiotic should be included in the empiric coverage, because TMP-SMX does not cover this organism.

Indications for hospitalization and intravenous antibiotic treatment include high fevers, rapid progression of infection, abscesses overlying joint spaces or the hands or feet, and failure of outpatient therapy with oral antibiotics.

Key learning point: A patient who has symptoms and signs of a moderately large skin abscess without overlying cellulitis but with some systemic inflammatory symptoms should be managed with incision and drainage as well as oral antibiotics.

B) INCORRECT:

Indications for intravenous antibiotic treatment include high fevers, rapid progression of infection, abscesses overlying joint spaces or the hands or feet, and failure of outpatient therapy with oral antibiotics. This patient can be treated with oral antibiotics.

C) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics alone are not sufficient for the management of an abscess.

D) INCORRECT:

Indications for hospitalization and intravenous antibiotic treatment include high fevers, rapid progression of infection, abscesses overlying joint spaces or the hands or feet, and failure of outpatient therapy with oral antibiotics. This patient can be treated with oral antibiotics as an outpatient.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics alone are not sufficient for the management of an abscess.

questions.text:
A fully immunized 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department (ED) the day after he punched another student in the mouth and nose at school. He reports that he sustained several small cuts on the back of his hand, which he washed in the sink at home. This morning, he noted increasing pain, redness, and swelling in his right hand and was brought to the ED by his mother.
On physical examination, he has three 1-cm lacerations on the dorsal surface of his right hand, overlying the third, fourth, and fifth metacarpals. He also has a 4-cm area of erythema, swelling, tenderness, and warmth underlying the lacerations.
Which one of the following antibiotics is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The wounds this patient sustained are likely due to contact with the teeth of the student he hit in the mouth. Wounds from the human mouth arising in such a situation should be treated as human bite wounds. Human bites can result in scratches, punctures, lacerations, and avulsions. The microbiology of human bite wounds is typically polymicrobial and reflects human mouth flora, skin flora, and the environment. The pathogens most commonly isolated from these wounds are Streptococcus species, Staphylococcus species, Eikenella corrodens, and anaerobes.

The risk for infection after a human bite is determined by the patient’s immunocompetence, the location of the bite, and local wound care. Patients with diabetes mellitus, sickle cell anemia, asplenia, and other immunocompromised states are at highest risk for infection. Wounds over a tendon, joint, or bone are at particularly high risk for infection, and studies have shown that puncture wounds are associated with up to a twofold increase in infection risk. Human bite wounds on a clenched fist, over the knuckles of the hand (sometimes called “fight bites”), are among the most serious because they can lead to septic arthritis or osteomyelitis.

Bite wounds usually result in infection as quickly as 8 to 12 hours after the bite. If the patient is seen more than 24 hours after the bite with no signs of infection, antibiotics are typically not recommended.

Amoxicillin-clavulanate is the antibiotic of choice for preventing and treating bite-wound infections; the amoxicillin component covers streptococcal species and E. corrodens, while the clavulanate, a beta-lactamase inhibitor, allows the amoxicillin to kill beta-lactamase-producing staphylococcus and oral anaerobes. Amoxicillin is not sufficient alone as it will not cover these beta-lactamase-producing organisms. For penicillin-allergic patients, clindamycin combined with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is an alternative for preventing and treating bite-wound infections.

A tetanus booster should be given to all patients with bite wounds whose immunization status is unknown or if more than 5 years have elapsed since the patient’s last booster. Other essential steps in managing an infected bite wound include obtaining cultures when possible, irrigating with sterile normal saline, exploring directly with or without imaging, debriding devitalized tissue, draining any areas of fluid collection, and potentially repairing the wound, as well as assessing risk for transmission of bloodborne pathogens such as hepatitis viruses and HIV.

Key learning point: The recommended first-line antibiotic treatment for an infected human bite wound is amoxicillin-clavulanate.

B) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline covers some of the aforementioned organisms, but not the anaerobes or gram-negative organisms frequently implicated in human bite infections.

C) INCORRECT:

Erythromycin covers some of the aforementioned organisms, but not the anaerobes or gram-negative organisms frequently implicated in human bite infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Fluoroquinolones such as moxifloxacin have good activity against most bite-wound microbes, but their spectrum of activity is too broad to recommend for empiric use for bite wounds.

E) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin is not sufficient alone as it will not cover beta-lactamase-producing organisms.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with type 2 diabetes and hypertension who recently recovered from a diarrheal illness reports several days of perianal and testicular pain that has become worse during the past 3 days. His medications include insulin glargine, metformin, lisinopril, and metoprolol. On physical examination, his temperature is 38.8°C, his heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. The skin over his lower abdomen, perineum, and scrotal area is erythematous, with crepitus and excruciating pain upon touch. Which one of the following initial management approaches is most appropriate in this case?

choices.text: Surgical debridement plus intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Fournier gangrene is a necrotizing fasciitis involving the perineal area; involvement can include the scrotum, penis, and anterior abdominal wall, in addition to the perineum. Patients with diabetes mellitus are at a particularly high risk for this infection. Initial symptoms include pain, erythema, and swelling. As the process evolves, purulent drainage, bullous lesions, tissue necrosis, and subcutaneous crepitus may develop. This aggressive infection warrants urgent treatment with both surgical debridement and intravenous antibiotics. Broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy should cover gram-positive, gram-negative, and anaerobic organisms.

Key learning point: In addition to antibiotic therapy, the most appropriate management for a man with type 2 diabetes and Fournier gangrene is surgical debridement.

B) INCORRECT:

This clinical presentation is not a typical manifestation of fungal infection; hence fluconazole is not appropriate therapy. Candidal intertrigo may manifest with striking erythema of the scrotum and groin, but it is a superficial infection and does not cause systemic toxicity.

C) INCORRECT:

Fournier gangrene requires urgent treatment with both surgical debridement and intravenous antibiotics. Surgical debridement alone without antibiotic coverage is not sufficient.

D) INCORRECT:

Fournier gangrene requires urgent treatment with both surgical debridement and intravenous antibiotics. Broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy should cover gram-positive, gram-negative, and anaerobic organisms; vancomycin monotherapy is not sufficient.

E) INCORRECT:

Fournier gangrene requires urgent treatment with both surgical debridement and intravenous antibiotics. Intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage alone without surgical debridement is not sufficient.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the office because of a 2-day history of redness, swelling, and pain of the right leg. During this time, he also has had fever, chills, and nausea. He reports seeing liquid oozing from the affected area on his right leg. He is tachycardic and febrile. Examination of the right lower leg shows a large area of erythema with poorly-demarcated borders and purulent drainage. The area is fluctuant, warm, and tender to touch. Examination of the right groin shows several enlarged, tender lymph nodes. In addition to incision, drainage, and taking cultures from the wound, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin is effective against gram-positive bacteria including MRSA. While clindamycin is one of the recommended empiric antibiotics for nonpurulent cellulitis in patients who do not require parenteral therapy, it is not recommended for purulent cellulitis. In this patient with systemic signs of infection (tachycardia, fever), oral clindamycin is not appropriate.

B) CORRECT:

Intravenous vancomycin is effective against gram-positive bacteria including MRSA, making it the empirical treatment of choice for patients with purulent cellulitis and systemic signs of infection (e.g., tachycardia, fever). Since infection by MRSA is becoming increasingly common, an antibiotic that covers MRSA is also required for empirical therapy in patients with a history of recent hospitalization, recent antibiotic use, penetrating trauma, injection drug use, or evidence of MRSA infection or colonization elsewhere. Once culture and sensitivity results are available, a more targeted approach to antibiotic therapy should be pursued.

See “Empiric antibiotic therapy for nonpurulent and purulent SSTIs” table.

C) INCORRECT:

For patients with cellulitis, surgical debridement is indicated in the case of recurrent infection and/or necrotizing fasciitis, and if cellulitis continues to spread despite appropriate antibiotic therapy. This patient has no evidence of necrotizing fasciitis such as pain out of proportion to the area of erythema, skin necrosis, or crepitus.

D) INCORRECT:

Although cephalexin, like all first-generation cephalosporins, is effective against Staphylococcus aureus, it is ineffective against MRSA and, therefore, not the treatment of choice for empiric therapy of purulent cellulitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin is not effective against gram-positive bacteria such as Staphylococcus aureus and is, therefore, not used for the empiric treatment of cellulitis.
questions.hint: Tender, erythematous skin with diffuse borders that is draining pus is most likely the result of purulent cellulitis, which is most commonly caused by Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). In addition to incision and drainage, systemic antibiotic therapy is indicated for purulent cellulitis with systemic signs of infection (e.g., fever, tachycardia) and/or immunosuppression.

questions.text: A previously healthy 5-year-old boy is brought to the office because of a 2-day history of a rash and swelling on his left lower leg. His mother says the boy complained of an insect bite while playing outdoors 3 days before the onset of the lesion. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F) and pulse rate is 120/min. The lower left leg is swollen and tender with sharply demarcated erythema. There is also a narrow red line with a raised border that extends from the lower leg to the groin. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is a rare cause of nonpurulent skin and soft tissue infections (SSTIs). This pathogen sometimes causes nonpurulent cellulitis, which affects the deep tissue and therefore manifests with poorly demarcated erythema. This patient has sharply demarcated erythema. In addition, lymphangitis is typically not discernable in cellulitis; induration is expected instead. This patient has erysipelas, which is not associated with S. aureus infection.

This is a difficult question, and S. aureus is a good answer choice to consider because it is the most common cause of purulent SSTIs (e.g., impetigo, abscess, folliculitis). However, nonpurulent SSTIs, especially erysipelas, are more commonly caused by another pathogen. The choice of empiric antibiotic therapy in patients with SSTIs depends on the likelihood of S. aureus involvement. Knowing the microbial spectrum of skin infections has a direct impact on patient care, and using the most specific antibiotic agent (also in empiric approaches) is necessary as part of antimicrobial stewardship. Patients with erysipelas may be treated with an empiric antibiotic that does not cover S. aureus (e.g., penicillin).

B) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus epidermidis usually becomes pathogenic in immunocompromised patients, especially those with invasive devices like catheters, central lines or surgical implants. This child has no risk factors for a S. epidermidis infection, making it an unlikely cause of his symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Sporothrix schenckii causes sporotrichosis, which typically manifests with localized inflammation and a lesion at the site of entry, similar to what is seen in this patient. Sporotrichosis is a good differential diagnosis to consider when evaluating patients with skin injuries who have been in close contact with soil and/or plant matter because S. schenckii is commonly transmitted from plant material through skin lesions (e.g., thorn prick while playing outside). However, sporotrichosis manifests with nodules, pustules, and ulcers along the draining lymphatics (nodular lymphangitis) rather than a continuous red streak. Additionally, systemic symptoms (e.g., fever) are usually absent. Erysipelas, which this patient has, is not typically caused by S. schenckii.

D) INCORRECT:

Contact dermatitis results in large, itchy rashes. This child has a history of an insect bite, to which some patients are allergic, but swelling and tenderness of the leg along with fever suggests an infection rather than contact dermatitis.

E) CORRECT:

Group A streptococci (GASs), such as Streptococcus pyogenes, are the most common cause of nonpurulent skin and soft tissue infections (SSTIs), such as erysipelas, nonpurulent cellulitis, lymphangitis. The point of entry for pathogens in erysipelas is usually a minor skin lesion (e.g., insect bites, rhagades, athlete's foot, ulcers, blisters) from where the pathogen spreads via lymphatic vessels, resulting in infection of the upper dermis. The lower limbs and face are most commonly affected. Sharply demarcated erythema helps differentiate erysipelas from deep tissue infections such as cellulitis, which are characterized by erythema with indistinct margins. Because GASs typically do not produce penicillinase (unlike S. aureus, the most common cause of other, mostly purulent SSTIs, such as folliculitis), nonsevere erysipelas may be treated with penicillin.

Key learning point: Erysipelas, characterized by fever and sharply demarcated erythema, is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (group A streptococcus).
Image Description:

A sharply demarcated erythematous rash with discrete narrowing extensions is visible on the lower leg of this patient.

Location and appearance of the lesion are typical of a bacterial infection with Group A Streptococcus affecting the upper dermis and lymphatic vessels.
questions.hint: The narrow red line on this patient's leg suggests lymphangitis, which, in conjunction with classic signs of inflammation (swelling, tenderness), systemic symptoms (e.g., fever), and sharply demarcated erythema of the lower leg, raises suspicion for erysipelas.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man who recently underwent coronary artery bypass graft surgery presents to the emergency department with complaints of redness and tenderness in his left leg during the past 24 hours. He began experiencing leg pain one week ago, but he attributed it to the incision from the vein graft harvest site from his recent coronary artery bypass graft. He has had no fevers, chills, trauma to the area, or exposure to pets. On examination, he appears well and is afebrile. There is a well-demarcated, raised, bright-red erythematous area that surrounds the site of the surgical incision and appears superficial. No crepitus, purulence, bullae, or fluctuance is appreciated. Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in the care of this patient?

choices.text: Initiate treatment with intravenous immunoglobulin and clindamycin
Culture an aspirate from the involved subcutaneous tissue
Initiate treatment with penicillin-based antibiotic therapy
Obtain an MRI of the leg
Obtain a radiograph of the leg

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immunoglobulin and clindamycin (along with other antibiotics) would be indicated if the patient appeared to have toxic shock syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Culturing an aspirate from the involved subcutaneous tissue is not helpful because the lesion appears to be a dermal infection rather than a purulent fluctuant abscess.

C) CORRECT:

The classic features of erysipelas include a raised lesion above the level of the surrounding skin, a clear line of demarcation between involved and uninvolved tissue, and a brilliant salmon-red color to the lesion. Erysipelas is a superficial cutaneous process that is usually caused by group A streptococci but can be caused by other beta-hemolytic streptococci. The treatment is penicillin-based therapy.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for erysipelas is a penicillin-based antibiotic regimen.

D) INCORRECT:

Obtaining an MRI of the leg is not useful, as the infection appears to be superficial, and the patient appears to be well with normal vital signs and no evidence of necrotizing fasciitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Obtaining a radiograph to evaluate for air is not necessary because the skin process appears to be superficial, without evidence of fluctuance, crepitus, or purulence.

questions.text: A healthy 30-year-old man reports bumps on his legs that are occasionally itchy and that come and go but are particularly bothersome in the summer. He otherwise feels well. Physical examination reveals 1- to 2-mm papules and pustules centered around hair follicles and scattered on the patient’s thigh (figure). No comedones are visualized, and the patient does not have lesions elsewhere on his body. Which one of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient’s rash?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous herpes simplex virus infections are characterized by grouped vesicles, papules, or pustules on an erythematous base, often on the lips or buttocks. They do not appear as scattered, follicle-based papules and pustules, as seen in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa can cause folliculitis in patients exposed to contaminated water, such as in pools and hot tubs. Folliculitis caused by Pseudomonas may appear in exposed areas of the legs and may have more peripheral erythema.

C) INCORRECT:

Candida albicans can cause folliculitis in immunocompromised patients, especially when they have candidemia. It can also cause pustular folliculitis in the skin folds of immunocompetent patients. However, it is not the most likely causative agent in this healthy, young patient whose folliculitis occurs exclusively on the legs.

D) INCORRECT:

Cutibacterium acnes, a gram-positive bacterium, is linked to the development of acne. Acne can appear as scattered papules and pustules, similar to folliculitis, but it usually also has concomitant open and closed comedones (blackheads and whiteheads, respectively). This is because unlike folliculitis, acne results from an alteration (with or without inflammation) in the follicular apparatus. Comedones are the uninflamed lesions, whereas papules, pustules, and nodules are the inflamed lesions.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has folliculitis, a condition that can occur when there is inflammation of the superficial hair follicle.

Folliculitis is commonly exacerbated by hot weather, tight-fitting clothing, and shaving. It can be caused by a variety of organisms, but the most common is Staphylococcus aureus. Obtaining a proper history of comorbid conditions, exposures, and medications can be helpful in determining the causative organism.

Mild bacterial folliculitis is treated with topical therapies such as mupirocin cream, clindamycin lotion or solution, and benzoyl peroxide. More extensive folliculitis may require oral antibiotics such as cephalexin or doxycycline. Wound cultures in these cases may be helpful in directing treatment but are not typically necessary.

Key learning point: Staphylococcus aureus is the organism most likely to cause bacterial folliculitis in an otherwise healthy patient without exposure to other relevant organisms.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male college student reports 3 days of increasing pain and swelling of a small nodule on his left posterior thigh. He attributes the symptoms to a possible spider bite and says that another student on his intramural wrestling team had a similar “bite.” He states that he has not had any fevers, chills, or other systemic symptoms. He is afebrile, and his vital signs are normal. Examination reveals a 3-cm erythematous, tender, fluctuant nodule on his left posterior thigh. His leukocyte count is normal. Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Incision and drainage of the abscess plus adjunctive trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
Cephalexin plus incision and drainage of the abscess

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cephalexin does not have activity against MRSA.

B) CORRECT:

Community-acquired methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) strains are a common cause of skin and soft-tissue infections, in particular, abscess formation. Initially, outbreaks occurred among sports teams, children at childcare centers, prison inmates, military trainees, and men who have sex with men. However, infections from community-acquired MRSA can now affect any population.

Suspicion for MRSA infection should be high in patients with risk factors for the condition and in patients who present with skin or soft-tissue abscesses with or without cellulitis. The appearance of follicular or skin abscesses caused by MRSA can mimic spider bites, and patients often mistake the abscesses as insect bites.

Optimal initial management for a skin abscess from community-acquired MRSA is incision and drainage. Whether or not to include adjunctive antibiotic therapy has been a matter of debate. Current guidelines recommend incision and drainage alone for uncomplicated abscesses measuring < 2 cm, but recent data suggest that even in smaller abscesses, there may be a higher cure rate if antibiotics are administered. For larger abscesses (as seen in this case), adjunctive antimicrobial therapy is warranted. Support for this approach comes from a recent clinical trial showing benefit from the use of adjunctive trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole with incision and drainage in patients with uncomplicated skin abscess. The trial involved patients with lesions that had been present for less than one week and that measured ≥ 2 cm; MRSA was found in approximately 45% of participants. Similar findings were noted in another trial of abscesses < 5 cm in size where the causative organism was MRSA in 67% of cases; the cure rate was similar in the groups receiving clindamycin or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (around 82%), and both groups had higher cure rates than the placebo group (69%).

Key learning point: Optimal management for a 3-cm skin abscess caused by community-acquired methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus without associated systemic symptoms is incision and drainage plus adjunctive trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

C) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole treats MRSA, but without incision and drainage, it is not adequate treatment for skin abscesses.

D) INCORRECT:

For larger abscesses, adjunctive antimicrobial therapy is warranted, but cephalexin is not an appropriate choice for MRSA, because it does not have activity against MRSA.

E) INCORRECT:

Dicloxacillin does not have activity against MRSA.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl reports a 4-day history of swelling and pain in her right inguinal area. She appreciated increased swelling and tenderness a few days after noticing an ingrown hair in the area. She has a temperature of 38.2°C (100.8°F) and appears well. Along her right inguinal crease is a 7-cm x 5-cm area of induration with central fluctuance that is tender to palpation. There is no erythema, streaking, or crepitus. Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate to manage this patient’s skin lesion?

choices.text: Incision and drainage plus oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
Incision and drainage plus intravenous cefazolin

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Definitive treatment for a large abscess, as in this case, consists of incision and drainage plus an antibiotic, such as trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX), that covers community-acquired methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Alternative antibiotics that cover MRSA include doxycycline and clindamycin. A recent study demonstrated that providing TMP-SMX after incision and drainage of an abscess resulted in higher rates of clinical cure than incision and drainage alone. In another trial, involving abscesses <5 cm in size where the causative organism was MRSA in 67% of cases, the cure rate was similar in groups receiving clindamycin or TMP-SMX after incision and drainage (around 82%), and both groups had higher cure rates than the placebo group (69%).

Antibiotics alone, either oral or intravenous, without incision and drainage, is not sufficient for management of an abscess.

Although TMP-SMX is adequate treatment for an abscess, it would not be sufficient treatment if the patient also had signs and symptoms of cellulitis. In the presence of cellulitis, Streptococcus pyogenes could be considered as a potential pathogen, and a beta-lactam antibiotic should be included in the empiric coverage, because TMP-SMX does not cover this organism. The absence of erythema suggests that an overlying cellulitis is unlikely, and the absence of high fever, exquisite pain, or crepitus indicates that a rapidly progressing infection, such as necrotizing fasciitis, is also unlikely.

Indications for hospitalization and intravenous antibiotic treatment include high fevers, rapid progression of infection, abscesses overlying joint spaces or the hands or feet, and failure of outpatient therapy with oral antibiotics.

Key learning point: A patient who has symptoms and signs of a moderately large skin abscess without overlying cellulitis but with some systemic inflammatory symptoms should be managed with incision and drainage as well as oral antibiotics.

B) INCORRECT:

Indications for intravenous antibiotic treatment include high fevers, rapid progression of infection, abscesses overlying joint spaces or the hands or feet, and failure of outpatient therapy with oral antibiotics. This patient can be treated with oral antibiotics.

C) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics alone are not sufficient for the management of an abscess.

D) INCORRECT:

Indications for hospitalization and intravenous antibiotic treatment include high fevers, rapid progression of infection, abscesses overlying joint spaces or the hands or feet, and failure of outpatient therapy with oral antibiotics. This patient can be treated with oral antibiotics as an outpatient.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics alone are not sufficient for the management of an abscess.
questions.hint: Given this patient's clinical signs and symptoms and the moderately large area of induration and fluctuance around the site of a prior skin lesion, the patient likely has an abscess secondary to Staphylococcus aureus.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man presents with a 5-day history of increasing pain and swelling in his right buttock. He reports subjective fevers and chills. He has mild hyperglycemia but no other comorbidities. Examination shows an erythematous, tender, and fluctuant area measuring approximately 7 cm in diameter (see lab result and report).


Heart rate
105/min


Blood pressure
110/70 mmHg


Temperature
38.5°C




Test
Result
Normal Values


WBC
18 x 109/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 109/L


Ultrasound: Large fluid collection
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform immediate needle aspiration in the office
Apply warm compresses and reevaluate in 48 hours
Prescribe oral antibiotics and schedule outpatient follow-up
Start IV antibiotics and consult surgery for drainage

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Needle aspiration may be appropriate for small or superficial abscesses. However, the 7 cm abscess with systemic inflammatory signs and ultrasound-confirmed fluid collection likely contains thick or loculated purulent material, unsuitable for needle aspiration. The office setting may lack the sterile environment and procedural capabilities for complete drainage.

B) INCORRECT:

Warm compresses can aid early or minor soft tissue infections by increasing blood flow. However, the 7 cm fluctuant collection and ultrasound findings indicate a well-formed abscess. Systemic signs, including fever and leukocytosis, suggest an active infection requiring intervention rather than conservative management.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics may be suitable for mild soft tissue infections, such as uncomplicated cellulitis. However, the fluctuant 7 cm area, ultrasound evidence of a large fluid collection, fever, tachycardia, and elevated white blood cell count suggest an abscess. Abscesses have poor vascularity and purulent material, making oral antibiotics ineffective. The size and systemic signs necessitate direct intervention.

D) CORRECT:

A deep abscess in a patient with diabetes manifests with significant local inflammation and systemic infection signs. The patient's fever, tachycardia, and elevated white blood cell count, along with ultrasound evidence of a large fluid collection, indicate a deep-seated abscess. Diabetic patients are more prone to severe infections due to impaired immune responses and microvascular changes. Management requires source control through drainage and systemic coverage with intravenous antibiotics to eradicate the infection. Surgical consultation is crucial for proper drainage, reducing the infectious burden, and preventing complications.

Key learning point: In cases of large abscesses with systemic infection signs, management should include IV antibiotics and surgical consultation for potential drainage.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man presents with a 3-day history of progressive redness and swelling in his left lower leg. He reports a minor abrasion from yard work just before these symptoms began. Examination shows the area is warm, tender, and erythematous with indistinct borders. He has a low-grade fever and mild chills. Peripheral pulses are intact, and no crepitus is noted.
Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erysipelas is an acute infection of the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics, presenting as a bright red, raised, and sharply demarcated area. Indistinct borders, as seen here, do not align with erysipelas, which typically has well-defined, raised margins.

B) INCORRECT:

Deep venous thrombosis (DVT) is characterized by unilateral leg swelling and discomfort, but it does not present with localized erythema with indistinct borders. DVT is more commonly associated with diffuse swelling and pain along the deep venous system, without systemic signs like fever and chills.

C) INCORRECT:

Necrotizing fasciitis typically presents with pain out of proportion to physical findings, rapid systemic deterioration, and features like crepitus, bullae, or skin necrosis. The mild systemic symptoms and indistinct borders here suggest a more superficial infection.

D) CORRECT:

Cellulitis manifests with a warm, tender, and erythematous area with indistinct borders, typically on the lower leg. It involves an infection of the dermis and subcutaneous tissue, often caused by β-hemolytic streptococci or Staphylococcus aureus entering through a skin break. The inflammatory response leads to localized swelling, redness, and tenderness. Systemic symptoms like low-grade fever and chills reflect the body's immune response. The progression from an initial injury over several days aligns with cellulitis, where the infection gradually spreads through soft tissues.

Key learning point: Cellulitis is characterized by localized swelling, erythema, tenderness, and fever, and is a common bacterial infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissues.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man with diabetes presents with a two-day history of progressive swelling, redness, and warmth of his left lower leg. He reports a small foot cut several days ago. He has a low-grade fever but no systemic symptoms. Examination reveals tenderness on palpation and redness that is not sharply demarcated (see lab result).

Temperature
37.8 °C



Test
Result
Normal Values


WBC
12 x 109/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 109/L


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erysipelas is characterized by a well-demarcated, raised border due to infection of the upper dermis and lymphatics. The patient's diffuse redness with indistinct margins and deeper tissue involvement are inconsistent with erysipelas, which typically presents with sharply defined edges.

B) INCORRECT:

Necrotizing fasciitis presents with rapidly progressive pain, deep tissue signs like crepitus, and systemic toxicity. The patient's low-grade fever, modest leukocytosis, and diffuse redness without severe pain or systemic instability do not align with this severe infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Contact dermatitis results from exposure to an allergen or irritant, causing a pruritic rash with a defined pattern. The patient's history of a foot cut, progressive symptoms, localized tenderness, and leukocytosis suggest an infection rather than contact dermatitis, which lacks systemic signs like fever.

D) CORRECT:

Cellulitis manifests with infection of the deeper dermis and subcutaneous tissue, presenting as localized swelling, redness, warmth, and tenderness, often following minor skin trauma. The erythema typically has ill-defined borders. Diabetes increases susceptibility to infections due to impaired tissue integrity and immune response. The patient's mild fever and elevated white blood cell count indicate an inflammatory response to bacterial invasion, commonly by Streptococcus species or Staphylococcus aureus.

Key learning point: Cellulitis is a common bacterial skin infection characterized by redness, swelling, warmth, and pain, often following a break in the skin, such as a cut or puncture wound.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman presents with a 3-day history of progressive swelling in her left thigh. She reports severe pain, fever, and chills. Examination reveals a tense, fluctuant area measuring about 5 cm in diameter, with overlying erythema, warmth, and purulent drainage at the edge. She appears ill (see lab results and report).


Heart rate
110/min


Temperature
38.9°C




Test
Result
Normal Values



WBC
15 × 10⁹/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 10⁹/L


C-reactive peptide
20 mg/L
< 8.2 mg/L



Doppler ultrasound: Fluid collection confirmed
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Oral antibiotics with local wound care
Percutaneous needle aspiration under ultrasound guidance
Surgical incision and drainage of the abscess

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous antibiotics alone are inadequate for managing an abscess, as the encapsulated pus limits antibiotic penetration. The patient has systemic signs of infection and a localized abscess, necessitating drainage to remove the infection source. Antibiotics alone cannot resolve the infection without addressing the walled-off collection.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics and local wound care are insufficient for this patient, who has a fluctuant abscess and systemic signs such as fever and elevated inflammatory markers. Abscesses require drainage for effective management, as antibiotics poorly penetrate the pus-filled environment. Without drainage, the infection source remains, risking further systemic spread.

C) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous needle aspiration may be considered for small or deep abscesses, but this patient has a superficial, fluctuant 5 cm abscess with systemic signs. Surgical drainage is more effective for complete evacuation and debridement, essential for resolving the infection and preventing recurrence.

D) CORRECT:

In cases of soft tissue infections with a well-circumscribed fluid collection and purulent material, surgical incision and drainage are crucial. This patient presents with fever, chills, tachycardia, and elevated inflammatory markers, indicating systemic involvement. Imaging confirms an abscess, necessitating surgical intervention to evacuate pus and remove necrotic tissue. This approach prevents further bacterial spread and reduces systemic inflammation. Surgical drainage, combined with appropriate antimicrobial therapy, addresses both local and systemic infection components, improving outcomes.

Key learning point: In cases of severe infection with purulent discharge and systemic symptoms, surgical drainage is often necessary to remove the source of infection and prevent further complications.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman presents with a 2-day history of a rapidly spreading, tender, bright-red rash on her left leg, accompanied by chills and fever. She has type 2 diabetes. She denies any open wounds or recent injuries. Examination shows a raised, sharply demarcated erythematous plaque with warmth and mild swelling. Laboratory results show leukocytosis with neutrophil predominance.
Which organism is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is often associated with purulent skin infections, abscesses, or wound infections. The patient's presentation of a rapidly spreading, tender, bright-red rash with a sharply demarcated and raised border suggests a uniform inflammatory process, not the localized purulence typical of S. aureus infections. The absence of an open wound or purulence further reduces the likelihood of S. aureus as the causative agent.

B) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa typically causes infections after exposure to moist environments, such as in burn wounds or hot tub folliculitis. It is more common in immunocompromised patients with clear wound entry points. The patient's presentation of a sharply demarcated erythematous plaque with systemic symptoms aligns more with erysipelas, usually caused by Gram-positive cocci, not Pseudomonas.

C) CORRECT:

Erysipelas manifests as an acute, sharply demarcated, raised erythematous plaque with systemic symptoms like fever and chills. Streptococcus pyogenes, a Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus, is the primary pathogen responsible for this condition. It colonizes minor skin breaks, triggering an intense inflammatory response. The patient's diabetes increases susceptibility to such infections by impairing immune defenses and skin integrity. Leukocytosis with neutrophil predominance supports a bacterial infection caused by this organism.

Key learning point: Erysipelas is characterized by a sharply demarcated, tender, red lesion often accompanied by fever, and is typically caused by Streptococcus pyogenes.

D) INCORRECT:

Pasteurella multocida is associated with infections following animal bites or scratches. The patient denies recent trauma or animal exposure, and the presentation of a sharply demarcated erythematous plaque is more typical of erysipelas. Diabetes predisposes to infections from skin commensals rather than Pasteurella, making it an unlikely cause.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents with a week of increasing pain and swelling at the back of his neck. He has poorly controlled type 2 diabetes and reports low-grade fevers and fatigue. Examination shows a 5-cm painful, erythematous swelling with fluctuant areas and multiple pustular openings that drain purulent fluid (see lab result).


Test
Result
Normal Values


WBC
12 x 10⁹/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 10⁹/L


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cellulitis is a diffuse soft tissue infection presenting with localized erythema, warmth, and tenderness. However, the presence of fluctuant areas and multiple pustular openings with purulent drainage suggests abscess formation, which is inconsistent with cellulitis. Cellulitis typically involves diffuse dermal and subcutaneous tissue inflammation without discrete collections or sinus tracts.

B) INCORRECT:

Pilonidal cysts typically occur in the sacrococcygeal region, particularly within the natal cleft, and are common in younger individuals. The lesion's location at the back of the neck and the patient's age make a pilonidal cyst unlikely. Additionally, poorly controlled diabetes predisposes to infections in non-traditional areas, supporting an alternative diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Furuncles are localized infections of a single hair follicle, presenting as solitary, tender, erythematous nodules with a central point of pus. The described lesion is large, with fluctuant regions and multiple pustular openings, indicating involvement of multiple adjacent hair follicles, not a single follicular infection.

D) CORRECT:

A carbuncle is a deep skin infection involving a cluster of interconnected furuncles, typically affecting multiple adjacent hair follicles. This patient, with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes, is predisposed to infections with Staphylococcus aureus, the primary pathogen in carbuncle development. Carbuncles present as large, erythematous, tender lesions with fluctuance and multiple pustular openings draining purulent fluid, indicating abscess formation. The systemic symptoms, such as low-grade fever and leukocytosis, suggest a systemic inflammatory response.

Key learning point: A carbuncle is characterized by a cluster of interconnected furuncles with multiple discharging sinuses, often seen in patients with diabetes.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man presents with severe left calf pain that started suddenly overnight. He has poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. The area is warm, erythematous, and exquisitely tender with ill-defined margins. Palpation reveals a crackling sensation beneath the skin (see lab results).


Heart rate
120/min


Blood pressure
90/60 mm Hg


Temperature
39.0°C




Test
Result
Normal Values



WBC
15 x 109/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 109/L


C-reactive peptide
20 mg/L
< 8.2 mg/L



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics and wait for imaging

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-dose intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) is considered in streptococcal toxic shock syndrome due to its ability to neutralize superantigens. However, this patient presents with a necrotizing soft tissue infection requiring immediate surgical intervention. IVIG does not provide the necessary source control for such infections.

B) INCORRECT:

Broad-spectrum antibiotics are essential in managing necrotizing infections, but they cannot replace surgical debridement. The patient's presentation suggests necrotizing fasciitis, and delaying surgery for imaging could lead to worse outcomes. Immediate surgical intervention is critical.

C) INCORRECT:

While contrast-enhanced MRI can delineate the extent of soft tissue infections, this patient exhibits clear signs of a necrotizing infection, such as severe pain, systemic toxicity, and crepitus. These findings make the diagnosis evident, and delaying treatment for imaging could worsen outcomes.

D) CORRECT:

Necrotizing soft tissue infections, particularly in patients with poorly controlled diabetes, require immediate surgical intervention. The sudden onset of severe pain, systemic signs of sepsis, and crepitus indicate a fulminant infection with subcutaneous gas. Surgical exploration allows for assessment and aggressive debridement of necrotic tissue, which is essential to control the infection and reduce systemic toxin release. This approach, combined with broad-spectrum antibiotics, is crucial for reducing mortality in rapidly progressing infections.

Key learning point: Necrotizing fasciitis is a surgical emergency requiring prompt and aggressive surgical debridement as the primary treatment.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of increasing pain and redness near a puncture wound on his left forearm. He reports chills and mild fever. He has no significant medical history and denies any recent travel or known exposures. Physical examination shows erythema radiating proximally from the wound toward the axilla, along with tender palpable cords.


Heart rate
90/min


Temperature
38.3°C


Which pathogen is most likely responsible for this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Streptococcus pyogenes, a Gram-positive, beta-hemolytic coccus, is a common cause of skin and soft tissue infections. It is known for causing lymphangitis, characterized by erythema spreading along lymphatic channels, resulting in tender, palpable cords. The patient's symptoms, including fever and chills, align with the aggressive nature of this pathogen. Its virulence factors, such as the M protein and exotoxins, facilitate rapid tissue invasion and inflammation. Prompt recognition and treatment are crucial to prevent complications.

Key learning point: Lymphangitis, characterized by red streaks radiating from a wound, is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes, a bacterium known for causing skin and soft tissue infections.

B) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus typically causes localized abscesses and purulent cellulitis, not the lymphangitic spread seen here. The erythema radiating proximally with tender cords suggests lymphangitis, more characteristic of beta-hemolytic streptococci. S. aureus infections are usually more localized and less associated with systemic symptoms like fever and chills.

C) INCORRECT:

Pasteurella multocida is linked to animal bites, especially from cats, and presents rapidly after the bite. The patient denies animal exposure, and the lymphangitic spread with erythema and tender cords is not typical for Pasteurella, which usually causes localized infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is associated with water exposure or nosocomial infections, often in immunocompromised patients. The absence of water exposure and the presence of lymphangitic spread make this pathogen unlikely. Pseudomonas typically causes infections in moist environments, not the lymphatic involvement seen here.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old student presents to the clinic with a warm, swollen, and painful area on her left ankle. She reports a minor abrasion in that region a few days earlier. Examination reveals faint red streaks extending proximally, tender lymph nodes in the popliteal and inguinal regions, mild fever, and minimal purulent discharge at the abrasion site. Her vital signs are stable.
Which antibiotic regimen is the most appropriate initial management for this condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous vancomycin is reserved for severe infections or high suspicion of MRSA. The patient's stable vital signs and localized cellulitis with lymphangitic spread suggest a non-purulent, uncomplicated infection likely due to streptococci. Vancomycin is unnecessary for this presentation, as beta-lactam antibiotics are effective for streptococcal cellulitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline is effective against community-associated methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) but does not reliably cover Streptococcus pyogenes. The patient's presentation, including red streaks and tender lymph nodes, is more indicative of streptococcal cellulitis than MRSA infection. Beta-lactam antibiotics are preferred for nonpurulent cellulitis without abscess formation.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is effective against MRSA but has limited activity against streptococci. The clinical features, including red streaking and tender lymph nodes, suggest streptococcal cellulitis rather than MRSA infection. Beta-lactam antibiotics are standard for streptococcal infections, making trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole less appropriate here.

D) CORRECT:

The clinical presentation of a warm, swollen, and painful area with red streaks and tender lymph nodes suggests lymphangitis, commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes. This Gram-positive bacterium often infects skin and soft tissues following minor skin breaches. Oral cephalexin, a first-generation cephalosporin, is effective against Streptococcus pyogenes. Its oral administration and activity against beta-hemolytic streptococci make it suitable for stable patients with non-severe infections. Cephalexin disrupts bacterial cell wall synthesis, leading to cell lysis, and is recommended for uncomplicated streptococcal cellulitis in outpatient settings.

Key learning point: Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus) is a common cause of lymphangitis and cellulitis, characterized by red streaks and swollen lymph nodes due to skin or soft tissue infections. Cephalexin is recommended for uncomplicated streptococcal cellulitis in outpatient settings.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 1-day history of rash on her trunk and lower extremities. Three days ago, she visited a spa resort with multiple swimming pools and whirlpools. A friend who accompanied her to the spa has developed a similar rash. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or take any medications. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there are multiple erythematous, excoriated papules and pustules over the trunk and upper thighs. Inflammation of which one of the following structures is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Inflammation of the hair follicles is the cause of folliculitis. This patient's history of visiting a spa resort and developing a pruritic, papulopustular rash is highly suggestive of hot tub folliculitis. This diagnosis is further supported by her friend developing similar symptoms. Though folliculitis is most commonly caused by S. aureus, hot tub folliculitis is characteristically caused by P. aeruginosa, which proliferates in wet and warm environments. This condition is typically self-limited and does not require antibiotic treatment.

Key learning point: Hot tub folliculitis is a self-limited, pruritic, papulopustular rash caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection and inflammation of hair follicles after exposure to contaminated warm water.
Image Description:

Multiple pustules with surrounding erythema can be seen emerging from the hair follicles.

B) INCORRECT:

The eccrine sweat glands contribute to thermoregulation by secreting sweat, which cools the body when water evaporates. Blockage of eccrine sweat glands, followed by exposure to heat, can cause miliaria, a condition that manifests with pruritic, papulopustular lesions. However, these lesions typically form in areas of the body that have a high concentration of eccrine sweat glands, such as the head, neck, and upper trunk. This patient's condition is caused by inflammation of a different structure.

C) INCORRECT:

Inflammation of the superficial epidermis is seen in many dermatologic conditions, including impetigo. This condition is a bacterial infection that typically manifests with a papulopustular rash, surrounding erythema, and erosions with a characteristic honey-colored crust, which is not seen in this patient. This patient's condition is caused by inflammation of a different structure.

D) INCORRECT:

Inflammation of the papillary dermis due to infection with S. pyogenes is the cause of erysipelas, which most commonly develops on the lower extremities. However, erysipelas typically manifests with well-demarcated, erythematous skin lesions with edema and warmth, not the papulopustular rash seen in this patient. This patient's condition is caused by inflammation of a different structure.

E) INCORRECT:

The sebaceous glands are a component of the pilosebaceous unit. Inflammation of the pilosebaceous unit causes acne vulgaris, which can manifest with a papulopustular rash. However, lesions of acne vulgaris are not typically pruritic and usually manifest during adolescence and young adulthood and in areas of the body that have a high concentration of sebaceous glands, such as the face, chest, and upper back. This patient's condition is caused by inflammation of a different structure.
questions.hint: This patient has a self-limited infection that typically manifests 8–48 hours after exposure to water contaminated by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

questions.text: You are seeing a 50-year-old man with type 2 diabetes and hypertension who recently recovered from a diarrheal illness. He reports several days of perianal and testicular pain that has worsened over the past 3 days. His medications are insulin glargine, metformin, lisinopril, and metoprolol. On examination, his temperature is 38.8°C, heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. The skin over his lower abdomen, perineum, and scrotal area is erythematous, with crepitus and severe pain on palpation. Which one of the following initial management approaches is most appropriate?

choices.text: Surgical debridement plus intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Fournier gangrene is a necrotizing fasciitis involving the perineal area; involvement can include the scrotum, penis, and anterior abdominal wall, in addition to the perineum. Patients with diabetes mellitus are at a particularly high risk for this infection. Initial symptoms include pain, erythema, and swelling. As the process evolves, purulent drainage, bullous lesions, tissue necrosis, and subcutaneous crepitus may develop. This aggressive infection warrants urgent treatment with both surgical debridement and intravenous antibiotics. Broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy should cover gram-positive, gram-negative, and anaerobic organisms.

Key learning point: In addition to antibiotic therapy, the most appropriate management for a man with type 2 diabetes and Fournier gangrene is surgical debridement.

B) INCORRECT:

This clinical presentation is not a typical manifestation of fungal infection; hence fluconazole is not appropriate therapy. Candidal intertrigo may manifest with striking erythema of the scrotum and groin, but it is a superficial infection and does not cause systemic toxicity.

C) INCORRECT:

Fournier gangrene requires urgent treatment with both surgical debridement and intravenous antibiotics. Broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy should cover gram-positive, gram-negative, and anaerobic organisms; vancomycin monotherapy is not sufficient.

D) INCORRECT:

Fournier gangrene requires urgent treatment with both surgical debridement and intravenous antibiotics. Intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage alone without surgical debridement is not sufficient.

E) INCORRECT:

Fournier gangrene requires urgent treatment with both surgical debridement and intravenous antibiotics. Surgical debridement alone without antibiotic coverage is not sufficient.

questions.text: You are seeing a previously healthy 5-year-old boy who is brought to your clinic with a 2-day history of rash and swelling on his left lower leg. His mother reports that he complained of an insect bite while playing outdoors 3 days before the lesion appeared. His temperature is 38.5°C and pulse rate is 120/min. The lower left leg is swollen and tender with sharply demarcated erythema. There is a narrow, raised, red line extending from the lower leg to the groin. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Group A streptococci (GASs), such as Streptococcus pyogenes, are the most common cause of nonpurulent skin and soft tissue infections (SSTIs), such as erysipelas, nonpurulent cellulitis, lymphangitis. The point of entry for pathogens in erysipelas is usually a minor skin lesion (e.g., insect bites, rhagades, athlete's foot, ulcers, blisters) from where the pathogen spreads via lymphatic vessels, resulting in infection of the upper dermis. The lower limbs and face are most commonly affected. Sharply demarcated erythema helps differentiate erysipelas from deep tissue infections such as cellulitis, which are characterized by erythema with indistinct margins. Because GASs typically do not produce penicillinase (unlike S. aureus, the most common cause of other, mostly purulent SSTIs, such as folliculitis), nonsevere erysipelas may be treated with penicillin.

Key learning point: Streptococcus pyogenes (group A strep) is the most common cause of erysipelas, a nonpurulent skin infection with sharply demarcated erythema and lymphangitis.
Image Description:

A sharply demarcated erythematous rash with discrete narrowing extensions is visible on the lower leg of this patient.

Location and appearance of the lesion are typical of a bacterial infection with Group A Streptococcus affecting the upper dermis and lymphatic vessels.

B) INCORRECT:

Contact dermatitis results in large, itchy rashes. This child has a history of an insect bite, to which some patients are allergic, but swelling and tenderness of the leg along with fever suggests an infection rather than contact dermatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus epidermidis usually becomes pathogenic in immunocompromised patients, especially those with invasive devices like catheters, central lines or surgical implants. This child has no risk factors for a S. epidermidis infection, making it an unlikely cause of his symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Sporothrix schenckii causes sporotrichosis, which typically manifests with localized inflammation and a lesion at the site of entry, similar to what is seen in this patient. Sporotrichosis is a good differential diagnosis to consider when evaluating patients with skin injuries who have been in close contact with soil and/or plant matter because S. schenckii is commonly transmitted from plant material through skin lesions (e.g., thorn prick while playing outside). However, sporotrichosis manifests with nodules, pustules, and ulcers along the draining lymphatics (nodular lymphangitis) rather than a continuous red streak. Additionally, systemic symptoms (e.g., fever) are usually absent. Erysipelas, which this patient has, is not typically caused by S. schenckii.

E) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is a rare cause of nonpurulent skin and soft tissue infections (SSTIs). This pathogen sometimes causes nonpurulent cellulitis, which affects the deep tissue and therefore manifests with poorly demarcated erythema. This patient has sharply demarcated erythema. In addition, lymphangitis is typically not discernable in cellulitis; induration is expected instead. This patient has erysipelas, which is not associated with S. aureus infection.

This is a difficult question, and S. aureus is a good answer choice to consider because it is the most common cause of purulent SSTIs (e.g., impetigo, abscess, folliculitis). However, nonpurulent SSTIs, especially erysipelas, are more commonly caused by another pathogen. The choice of empiric antibiotic therapy in patients with SSTIs depends on the likelihood of S. aureus involvement. Knowing the microbial spectrum of skin infections has a direct impact on patient care, and using the most specific antibiotic agent (also in empiric approaches) is necessary as part of antimicrobial stewardship. Patients with erysipelas may be treated with an empiric antibiotic that does not cover S. aureus (e.g., penicillin).
questions.hint: The narrow red line on this patient's leg suggests lymphangitis, which, in conjunction with classic signs of inflammation (swelling, tenderness), systemic symptoms (e.g., fever), and sharply demarcated erythema of the lower leg, raises suspicion for erysipelas.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to your clinic reporting bumps on his legs that are occasionally itchy and tend to come and go, but are especially bothersome during the summer. He otherwise feels well. On examination, you observe 1- to 2-mm papules and pustules centered around hair follicles, scattered on his thighs (see figure). No comedones are present, and there are no lesions elsewhere on his body. Which one of the following organisms is the most likely cause of his rash?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has folliculitis, a condition that can occur when there is inflammation of the superficial hair follicle.

Folliculitis is commonly exacerbated by hot weather, tight-fitting clothing, and shaving. It can be caused by a variety of organisms, but the most common is Staphylococcus aureus. Obtaining a proper history of comorbid conditions, exposures, and medications can be helpful in determining the causative organism.

Mild bacterial folliculitis is treated with topical therapies such as mupirocin cream, clindamycin lotion or solution, and benzoyl peroxide. More extensive folliculitis may require oral antibiotics such as cephalexin or doxycycline. Wound cultures in these cases may be helpful in directing treatment but are not typically necessary.

Key learning point: Staphylococcus aureus is the organism most likely to cause bacterial folliculitis in an otherwise healthy patient without exposure to other relevant organisms.

B) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa can cause folliculitis in patients exposed to contaminated water, such as in pools and hot tubs. Folliculitis caused by Pseudomonas may appear in exposed areas of the legs and may have more peripheral erythema.

C) INCORRECT:

Candida albicans can cause folliculitis in immunocompromised patients, especially when they have candidemia. It can also cause pustular folliculitis in the skin folds of immunocompetent patients. However, it is not the most likely causative agent in this healthy, young patient whose folliculitis occurs exclusively on the legs.

D) INCORRECT:

Cutibacterium acnes, a gram-positive bacterium, is linked to the development of acne. Acne can appear as scattered papules and pustules, similar to folliculitis, but it usually also has concomitant open and closed comedones (blackheads and whiteheads, respectively). This is because unlike folliculitis, acne results from an alteration (with or without inflammation) in the follicular apparatus. Comedones are the uninflamed lesions, whereas papules, pustules, and nodules are the inflamed lesions.

E) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous herpes simplex virus infections are characterized by grouped vesicles, papules, or pustules on an erythematous base, often on the lips or buttocks. They do not appear as scattered, follicle-based papules and pustules, as seen in this case.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man who is a college student comes to your clinic with a 3-day history of increasing pain and swelling of a small nodule on his left posterior thigh. He thinks the symptoms may be due to a spider bite and mentions that another member of his intramural wrestling team had a similar “bite.” He has not experienced fever, chills, or other systemic symptoms. He is afebrile and his vital signs are normal. On examination, there is a 3-cm erythematous, tender, fluctuant nodule on his left posterior thigh. His white blood cell count is normal. Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Cephalexin plus incision and drainage of the abscess.
Incision and drainage of the abscess plus adjunctive trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dicloxacillin does not have activity against MRSA.

B) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole treats MRSA, but without incision and drainage, it is not adequate treatment for skin abscesses.

C) INCORRECT:

For larger abscesses, adjunctive antimicrobial therapy is warranted, but cephalexin is not an appropriate choice for MRSA, because it does not have activity against MRSA.

D) CORRECT:

Community-acquired methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) strains are a common cause of skin and soft-tissue infections, in particular, abscess formation.
